segments.text: I'm alert today.
Go ahead.
You don't want to stagger these five minutes this time?
You don't want to stagger these five minutes?
No.
I don't want to go this time.
Well, I'll just start at the same time.
I'd like to begin today's interview actually with where the last interview ended.
I want you to talk some more about crustaceans.
What began your interest in them particularly?
and where you are in terms of your research now with crustaceans.
Last time you said that they intrigued you and that Gil Rowe at Woods Hole was involved in taking a look at them.
Oh, no, you're getting me into hot water, but go ahead.
When are you ready?
I'm ready.
All right.
Well, the crustaceans are...
interest to me because of the important role they play in the marine environment.
Crustaceans predominate in the pelagic, in the water column.
Perhaps some of the most
Numerous organisms on Earth, metazoan-type organisms, are copepods, which are an important link in many of the so-called food webs of the ocean.
And so I feel that for that kind of reason alone, however, my interests are in the bottom-dwelling forms, primarily bentonic forms.
And I was particularly stimulated because of the fact that the brachiorhyns, or the true crabs, tend to be shallow water forms.
They are very predominant in the shallow water on the continental shelf and become...
far less numerous but equally interesting in the deep water.
As a matter of fact, also, one of the largest of the crabs, of the true crabs, the giant red crab, as it's called, attracted my attention as a possible source of food.
I make the distinction of true crab because the Alaska king crab, for example, is not a true crab.
It is a hermit crab type.
And we have a large representative of that group in the Gulf of Mexico as well.
But this giant red crab is a true brack urine crab.
Now, in addition to that, I found some crabs in the bottom of the Gulf, which is, of course, around 12,000 feet.
which are very poorly known.
As a matter of fact, one of them is represented by, so far as I'm aware, only three specimens in the world.
And I have taken two of those three.
And as a consequence, with all the work I've done in the bottom of the Gulf, and since this is the only place that I've found it,
Of course, extremely curious as to how some of these forms are able to reproduce and to sustain the small populations they have.
It would be intriguing to think they live for long, long periods of time and that they're electoral, but on the other hand, I doubt that very much.
But nevertheless, the crabs are an interesting group.

Then, furthermore, another intriguing sort of thing is that the giant isopod, which is a crustacean group as well, which lives in the Gulf and the Caribbean, the largest isopod known, which measures up to around 12, 14 inches in length and about 4 12 to 5 inches wide, is, again, I think, a possible source of...
of food of a particular type.
And I was intrigued by the fact that I discovered that these things swim.
I think I mentioned this in a previous interview, but I'm not sure.
Most unlikely heavy-bodied creatures, swimmers, but apparently they do.
As a matter of fact, I know they do because I've taken movies of them in around 5,000 feet of water.
In addition to that, my wife and I have teamed up to describe a number of new species among a very fascinating group of crustaceans known as Galatheids.
These are a rather strange group related to hermit crabs.
They look very much like miniature lobsters.
And we've found these, as I believe I've mentioned previously, in all depths of the sea.
But the intriguing thing about them is that they sort out as to generic or taxonomic type very nicely.
There being a group belonging to a genus Munida, which exists
primarily, almost exclusively, in shelf and shallow upper continental slope waters, whereas the group Munidopsis tends to go into much deeper water.
And we find some very nice ecological separations of these forms and some very nice and interesting geographic distributions.
Here again, forms that are not terribly well known.
And then, of course, I was intrigued by that group that are so enigmatic, the polychelids, which are forms that we know next to nothing about.
As I have remarked repeatedly to students, I have no

a reason for understanding why we've never been able to photograph these things in our bottom photography or our movies, whereas most other groups are well represented in our photographic collection of deep sea organisms.
We know they're on the surface because we troll them, but we can't figure out unless they're extremely fast, which is possible,
in their movements, why we have not been able to obtain pictures of them.
And there are a lot of other things about them that are interesting.
I had a student, Dick Firth, who studied them for some years, and he couldn't figure out either why we didn't photograph them.
Now, I'm sure I've left some things out, but the crustaceans are
fascinating group of organisms.
They serve the sea as the insects serve on land.
As you know, there are very few insects in the sea, extremely small number.
We've got one out there, a bug, Halobates micans, that runs around on the surface of the sea.
But it's cosmopolitan or rather widely distributed species.
Other than that, there are very few insects in the marine environment.
Could you tell us a little bit about your work in underwater photography, these movies and photographic surveys you've done?
Yes.
I first got into bottom photography as a result of dredging some iron-rich
sediments, indurated sediments, consolidated sediments in the eastern Gulf of Mexico.
The thing that intrigued me, in addition to the fact that it's very high in iron content, was that there were some organisms living on the bits of iron stone.
And since rock is at a premium in the Gulf of Mexico,
exposed rock, I returned there rather repeatedly.
And what I wanted to do was prove two things.
One, that this was truly rock and was not something that had been dropped from old sailing vessels as ballast rock, but that it was in situ and formed there
in this very remote section, the center section of the eastern Gulf of Mexico.
And so I obtained a small bottom camera and began taking pictures.
I had surmised also, because of the nature of the organisms on this ironstone, that there had to be a current flowing at the bottom there, and yet
There were, at that time, there were very few records of deep bottom currents.
Now the depth here was on the order of 10,000, 10,000 to 11,000 feet, so that's fairly deep water.
There was no theoretical rationale in physical oceanography to explain this current, nor is it adequately explained right now.
I've got some ideas.
But I'm not certain about it.
I think the current may be related, actually, to the intensity of trade winds.
But that's gotten far afield at the moment.
At any rate, I got the photographs of the Ironstone after a lot of tries and then got very definite evidence of a bottom current.

And so although I'm a biologically inclined individual, I did publish a paper on the ironstone with some colleagues, and also on this bottom current, which was among the few bottom currents of any consequence that had been reported on at that time.
I became then intrigued because of the stills that I was getting of certain animals with the potential of using movies underwater in very deep water.
And unfortunately, I have such a backlog of work that I have not explored that properly and don't know whether I'll have enough years left to do it.
It is a very intriguing thing.
I ran into some problems of wanting to use a rather large Aeroflex camera with a large film reel and getting an underwater case to house it.
None was available on the market, so we had to fabricate our own.
cast around for months trying to find some suitable material large enough that would withstand the pressure.
And I thought, of course, it had to be aluminum.
I finally found that there was an extrusion plant that extruded tubing with a 16-inch ID and perhaps thick enough to work.
And the guy that I talked to was intrigued enough by it
to say, well, you could probably supply it to me for $300 or $400, enough to do the job.
This was an Air Force piece of equipment and was housed in a commercial plant.
Well, I thought everything was going to be go, and yet when I got down to cases with the actual company where the thing was, I found out, yeah, it probably would be $300 for the first two feet of it,
But it would cost me $16,000 for a startup fee.
So I went into that trouble.
Finally, we made one out of laminated.
We took a three-inch aluminum flat plate, cut it, and stacked it like so, and machined out the opening we wanted.
And then we had to put O-rings.
So we've got a stacked case of about eight different
or layers of this stuff.
And then we put in the port in the front.
It worked beautifully, except that it was necessary to anchor the ship.
And to anchor the ship in deep water takes some doing in the first place.
But I've done it.
But I must say that
There has been a marked change in the weather in the Gulf of Mexico in the last five years.
It is getting worse, and I believe it is a trend.
Just a personal belief that the wind fields are intensifying, and we have much more wind and rougher seas than we had in the 60s.
And therefore, it was hard for me to hold the ship at anchor
And thus I lost a lot of ship time.
And it would really require to do a beautiful job of underwater movies, which I wanted to do.
I had it all set to leave it on the bottom.
It would take a lot of ship time and a separate proposal of the National Science Foundation.
And right now I have just too many other things to do.
And maybe in my closing couple of years or so I'm going to try it.
I don't know.
Now, would you just leave this camera floating free down there?
No, it would be on a tripod, and I had it programmed so that it was on 15 seconds out of every 5 minutes, and I could leave it down for 36 hours.
And I would have to take a chance, is what I would find.
But what I was doing...

was and i got some pretty good stuff actually in the short time that i did use it was selecting the places where my trawling told me the organisms i would like to photograph were actually present now obviously we have to go through this metal calibration because whenever you drag a net through the water for plankton or whatever you drag a trawl on the bottom for bottom organisms
You always bring up the accumulated mass, which is, of course, spaced out here.
And what you hope is that your mean free path is not so disadvantageous to you that you miss most of the organisms.
But they obviously, in many instances, are scattered out.
And it's like a cloud chamber, or it's like a collision of molecules.
You may or you may not.
And what we deduce from what we get may be rather far from the truth.
But there's one thing I'm certain of, is that organisms are widely scattered in the bottom of the ocean.
And I'm pretty lucky to get in.
So I also baited it.
Now, this man, John Isaacs, has done some magnificent and fascinating work with bottom photography with a monster camera, which he
uses an entirely different technique, and his colleague out there, one of them, Hessler, Robert Hessler, has used it to advantage also.
They put a big five-gallon can loaded with rotten fish down, and then they've got the camera held aloft, and they just drop it.
Bang.
And then it's got a time-release magnesium bar, and that magnesium bar goes into solution, and after so many hours, the bar breaks loose in it.
The thing comes back to the surface, and I guess they've got radio stuff on it.
I don't know.
But at any rate, they attract organisms in, and it's fascinating to see those things come in.
Of course, it's time-lapse, so you've got a shot.
You can see these organisms come creeping in.
And you can see things sometimes swimming by, sedately moving crustaceans and
So if you do manage to get in touch with this man and get some kind of appointment, you must interrogate him about his monster camera because it's really very interesting.
Do you see the biggest potential in this being the observation of behavior or more qualitative sampling of what is there?
Well, we know both, obviously.
important things.

As far as we're concerned, we know so little about the deep ocean and its biota, biota in the sense of bacteria being plants, because there isn't much else down there in that plant life, maybe some fungi.
But at any rate, these things are so poorly known, and we know so little about the effects of pressure
We know so little about what controls the distribution of these organisms.
Well, we can surmise that food is important, but I'm talking about vertical distribution.
And although years ago pressure was ruled out as being significant, I'm quite sure that it is significant.
And I think that these kinds of things, photographic probes,
depicting the organism while we are testing them in other ways.
For example, using caged organisms with the camera in the cage could give us a great deal of information on behavior upon the susceptibility of the organism to various pressure effects and so on.
In addition, we probably can get some idea of how far away

these organisms can be attracted by scent, so to speak, by putting these baits down and having more than one camera to get an idea of where they are coming in from and how far out and so on and so on.
So, yeah, I think there's great potential.
It's very intriguing.
It's just another mode for man to satisfy his curiosity, I think.
You gentlemen, I'm sure, are aware of the importance of that to the welfare of all people, whether they be politicians or biologists, which are the same.
We're all biologists, biologically inclined.
Those are some of my photographs, too.
Yes, I was noticing those.
That's part of the reason I was asking about the photographs.
I'm interested, too, and do you think there's a permanent wind change in the, by permanent, I mean the next several years or so in the Gulf?
Well, now, I'm not an authority at all on that, but I would say this, that Reed Bryson at Wisconsin, a meteorologist who is controversial, has
made some worldwide studies of climatic change.

And indeed, he issued a report for the CIA, which you probably have recently seen, because of the potential impact of weather change phenomena on food supplies, and thus the possibility of world upheaval
as famine began to strike.
I think this is a real danger, that famine will trigger riots and uprisings that will be extremely serious.
Well, at any rate, some years back when the debate was going on among meteorologists, I followed some of it in the literature.
And at the same time, I was experiencing great changes in the climate of the Gulf.
Now, the changes that he's predicting are long-range changes.
And so I do not think that it's a minor perturbation.
I think, yes, it is important and a phase change.
It's possible.
Who knows?
I don't.
But it wouldn't take a lot to convince me that we are
moving possibly into another glacial period.
So I don't have any evidence for it.
I don't against it.
But at any rate, conjecture indicates it would be a darn good possibility.
